jo4neo
Interface ObjectGraph

public interface ObjectGraph

Interface used to interact with neo4j in an object oriented manner. An ObjectGraph instance is associated with a particular NeoService instance. It is thread safe and therefore you can only have one ObjectGraph instance per NeoService.

Author:
Taylor Cowan
See Also:
ObjectGraphFactory

get

org.neo4j.api.core.Node get(java.net.URI uri)
Looks up the node representation of a given uri. This method may update your graph if no node was previously allocated for the uri.

Returns:
the node representation of uri.

Unmarshal a collections of nodes into objects.

close

void close()
Closes this ObjectGraph after which it will be unavailable for use. Calling close is necessary, and should be called even if the application is halted suddenly. ObjectGraph's maintain a lucene index which may become corrupt without proper shutdown.

find

<A> jo4neo.fluent.Where<A> find(A a)
Begin fluent interface find. a should be a newly constructed instance as it's contents will be modified/initialized by this call. 
 
   Customer customer = new Customer();
   customer = graph.find(customer).where(customer.id).is(123).result();

Parameters:
a -
Returns:

count

long count(java.util.Collection<? extends java.lang.Object> values)
Counts child entities without loading objects into memory. This is preferable to using Collection.size(), which would load the full collection into memory. 
 
   Customer customer = new Customer();
   customer = graph.find(customer).where(customer.id).is(123).result();
   long numOrders = graph.count(customer.orders);

Parameters:
values - a collection value from a jo4neo annotated field.
Returns:

getAddedSince

<T> java.util.Collection<T> getAddedSince(java.lang.Class<T> t,
                                          java.util.Date d)
Returns a collection of entities added since d. Type t must be annotated with Timeline

See Also:
Timeline
